title:
Ismail Inceoglu on Instagram: ""PLAIGUE"
So it went from "What brushes do you use?" to "What's your prompt?"
It's a fact that many talented artists tasted the seductive artificial intelligence, but gave it up quickly. I was truly disappointed, because some of them are my idols. But at least they realised what a plague this whole scheme is. Which I can't say for the ones that chose to steal years of work and dedication and turn it into their "art". The ones that dare to call themselves an artist without ever touching a pencil in their lives. What a joke.
To the people who are just starting to paint in these difficult times - don't give up. Don't close your mind. What your imagination can create, artificial intelligence can only steal.
What kind of art are we even talking about when you can't even choose your own composition or colors. When you don't go through hundreds of variations in your own imagination. Don't deprive yourself of the most wonderful feeling in the world - having to create something on your own. Why skipping the most exciting part? Why jumping at the end when it's the journey that matters.
I refuse to acknowledge this madness. I refuse my work to turn into a database. As you can see, I am absolutely against it. I for one am happy that we are not alone and this community has risen!
Don't give up!
________
You know what to do if you want.
www.linktr.ee/seven.teenth

title: Stanford professor: Mass tech layoffs caused by 'social contagion'

last_post.content: The widespread layoffs are more because of copycat behavior than cost-cutting - https://www.businessinsider.com/stanford-professor-mass-layoffs-caused-by-social-contagion-companies-imitating-2023-2

If you don't mind playing old game (they sometimes have things that can make them a bit frustrating to play like difficulty curve, but they also have charm and stuff that you can't find anymore in recent games), *I highly recommend to give Little Big Adventure 2 a try* : https://www.gog.com/game/little_big_adventure_2

Why?
- it's a game with a *lot of charm*, cartoon/colorful characters and locations with *goofy dubbed dialogues*, but the scenario isn't that simplistic, it is about fighting fascism, *the characters have a lot of life*, some great humor it's not 100% serious, some locations that you don't see in modern games
- tank controls *action RPG*, something you don't see nowadays, get a bit of getting used to but kinda refreshing tbh
- the game *doesn't do that much handholding but it's not a problem*, it's actually less artificial, you have to talk to NPCs to find what to do next, but fortunately several NPCs know so you're usually not stuck, if you have you can ping me so I give you a hint
- there are glitches to bypass stuff if you're stuck anyway, and a new game + that acts as an easy mode
- *not that expensive*
- the difficulty curve is way more merciful than LBA1 and you don't need to play LBA1 first to get the plot
- impressive for a 1998 game

It's not perfect, there are some sexism for example (1998 game), and some jankyness, but it's not that bad honestly (I'm less ashamed about it than Okami)

And more importantly, *they're making a reboot* that would fix some problems (like give women characters more importance and modernise gameplay and art style) and they need to prove that a lot of people like this game to prove to publishers that there is money to be made (capitalism... :<)

Please try it if you feel like you might like it, it's a great experience

This sort of book often gets bogged down in the "here's how terrible things are and why they are that way" section and then comes up short in the "here's what you can do about it" section. Rebecca Giblin and Cory Doctor (@pluralistic@mamot.fr) don't fall into that trap. Their things we can do are big things, and they'll take a lot of us working together, but I believe they can be done and they will make things better.

If you've been reading Cory's blog for any amount of time you'll had read some of this already, but by no means all of it, plus I think it's really beneficial to have everything all in one place and the links between the parts mapped out.

(comment on "Chokepoint Capitalism")
